results.title: Storm over Asia = Potomok Chingis-Khana
results.brief_description: Set during the British occupation of Mongolia in 1920, this is the half heroic, half ironic story of Bair, a young Mongolian hunter-turned-partisan who is captured. A document in his possession identifies him as a descendent of Genghis Khan. The interventionists decide to ‘resurrect’ him as a puppet king. However Bair escapes and leads the Mongolian army against the interventionists. The intensity of the drama, strong feeling for landscape and dramatic use of montage (four or five times the usual number of shots for a feature of this length) have been compared with the work of D.W. Griffith. In effect, the film is one long chase which takes on mythic proportions while the plot takes on metaphoric and lyrical dimensions (the British army is literally ‘blown away’). The emotional impact disguises the methodological rigour of Pudovkin’s construction. Also known as The Descendant of Genghis Khan. Cast includes Valeri Inkizhinov. This fully restored and digitally remastered version contains an original score by Timothy Brock performed by the Olympia Chamber Orchestra.

results.title: Storm of fire: World War II and the destruction of Dresden
results.brief_description: Presents a compelling documentary of the historical events that led to and included the destruction of Dresden, Germany, in February 1945. The events of the war between Germany and the Allies are followed from the early days of German victories to the eve of the bombing. The film shows the total devastation of Germany’s morale and strength. It is comprised of the actual sights and sounds of the events taken from archive footage and recordings. The culminating destruction is one of history’s terrible commentaries of the consequences and tragedy of total war.

results.title: Storm in a teacup
results.creator_credit: Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School and Stuart McDonald
results.brief_description: Cecil is retired and enjoying the twilight of his life. Freida is a widow who enjoys spending time at the local swimming pool, especially after she meets Cecil. Cecil and Freida soon become intimate companions (much to the amusement of some of Cecil’s mates from the croquet club), and Cecil becomes determined to fulfil his life-long dream of sailing to New Zealand - but is it too late? This film captures the essence of a generation who have plenty of time to enjoy themselves and is a positive look at senior citizens which illustrates that “old age” is really only as old as you feel!

results.title: Storm clouds over the colonies
results.creator_credit: Ronald Dick, John Howe and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Commonwealth of Nations”.
Tracing the history of the economic development of colonial territories, this film points out the shift in emphasis from the primary motives of discovery and the transfer of luxury goods to the establishment of permanent industries. The benefits of modern developments are weighed against exploitation, of which colonialism is never free. Narrated by Edgar McInnis.

results.title: Storm boy. - [Edited version]
results.creator_credit: Matt Carroll, South Australian Film Corporation, Learning Corporation of America and Henri Safran
results.brief_description: Edited version of the feature film of the same name produced in 1977. Story of a boy who lives with his widowed father in a comfortable but ramshackle beach house amidst coastal sand dunes in South Australia’s Coorong. He befriends three young pelicans orphaned by hunters who have shot the mother bird. Adapted from the book of the same title by Colin Thiele. Cast includes Peter Cummins, Greg Rowe, David Gulpilil.

results.title: Storm Boy [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Matt Carroll, South Australian Film Corporation and Henri Safran
results.brief_description: Three characters live in isolation amidst the coastal sand dunes of the Corrong in southern South Australia. In a shack on the beach live Tom, a fisherman and his young son; out amongst the dunes lives an aborigine, ‘Fingerbone Bill’ who forms a friendship with the boy, naming him ‘Storm Boy’. The story is conveyed with simplicity with many events left unspoken and undetailed. The relationships between the characters, and the scenes where the boy and his pet pelicans play together are subtley sketched and never lapse into the cloying sentimentality apparent in so many children’s films. Burton’s photography effectively captures the wild beauty of the Coorong.

results.title: Storm Boy
results.creator_credit: Matt Carroll, Henri Safran and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Storm Boy is a 1976 Australian drama film based on the book of the same name by Colin Thiele, about a lonely boy and his pet pelicans living in a coastal wilderness with his reclusive father.

constellations_other.name: David Dalaithngu
constellations_other.description: David Dalaithngu was a Yolngu man of the Mandhalpuyngu speech of the Djinba language. As a young boy, Dalaithngu was an accomplished hunter, tracker and dancer, which he turned into an acclaimed film career that saw him win the Best Actor award at the Cannes Film Festival (for Charlie's Country) and an AACTA for The Tracker, among his many honours.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Matt Carroll, Henri Safran and South Australian Film Corporation
results.description: Three characters live in isolation amidst the coastal sand dunes of the Coorong in southern South Australia. In a shack on the beach live Tom, a fisherman, and his young son; out amongst the dunes lives an Indigenous man, ‘Fingerbone Bill’, who forms a friendship with the boy, naming him ‘Storm Boy’. The story is conveyed with simplicity, with events being left unspoken and undetailed. The relationships between the characters, and the scenes where the boy and his pet pelican play together are subtly sketched. Burton’s photography effectively captures the wild beauty of the Coorong.

results.title: Storm at sea, tornado on land
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Kelly Lennon and ACMI
results.brief_description:
As Kelly Lennon ate breakfast, she knew it was going to be a miserable day. What followed was so terrifying that it was only when her mother returned that she felt safe.
On the 3rd of June 2010, the residents of Lennox Head, on the North Coast of New South Wales, were preparing for the day ahead when their town was struck by a tornado.

results.title: Storm and stress
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and colour and audio
results.brief_description: A line of satellite dishes stretches to the horizon as storm clouds loom overhead. A tornado funnels across a plains landscape at high speed. Through remarkable imagery of majestic natural phenomena, Storm and Stress evokes the beauty, terror and power of the tension between the forces of nature and technology. Hall’s sequences are based on natural elements — air, fire, water — and the industrial counterparts that echo them — wind tunnels, Tesla coils, hydroelectric plants. Hall’s allusions to Sturm und Drang, the 19th-century Romantic aesthetic of the apocalyptic sublime, and the notion of the Pathetic Fallacy, in which natural upheaval reflects the individual’s inner turmoil, are expressed through powerful visual metaphors.
